replies.text:
Yeah Dr. King & Fred Hampton realized black liberation is connected with all liberation movements. Same people who like idc about nobody but black people what they do for us. I‚Äôm like you do realize that people in power want right? 

Like I have met an Iraqi man or woman in my life but I knew them getting bombed in an illegal war was not good thing to do and understand only thing people suffering from war crimes got going on is they was born in wrong country. And I think lot of people worldwide don‚Äôt get that solidarity against fascism, imperialism and class struggle. They go to work, holla at they lover, do a hobby, watch tv and talk to family rinse repeat without ever realizing how truly insane world is and everyone being exploited by a group of greedy and insane people.

author: @Juniversal
text: Fantastic discussion. I love how Olay encapsulates voting for Biden over Trump as fighting my weakest enemy as opposed to lesser of two evils.

replies.author: @jayware4219
replies.text: But my issue with that argument is if you keep voting for them no matter what then they have no reason to actually listen to your demands. It‚Äôs the dems endorsing paying cops more and defending cop city for example. And they know they can get away with it because you‚Äôll vote for them anyway

replies.author: @Juniversal
replies.text: ‚Äã@jayware4219  Think you're missing the point. Fact is next election is going to be either Biden or Trump. Trump wins we regress. Biden wins we can conceivably push him from the left (which has proven beneficial on several policies).

replies.author: @nirvanaheights
replies.text: @jayware4219the alternative is having someone elected who will actively do their best to make your life hell. I will fight sleepy biden any day over satrump

replies.author: @Juniversal
replies.text: @jayware4219 Think you're missing the point. I'd never say you should be shamed or ashamed for withholding your vote but the fact is either Trump or Biden is going to win and withholding my vote is essentially voting for Trump (whose policies and isreal stance are 10x worse). I'd rather elect Biden and move him left then allow Trump to win and move further right.

replies.author: @mfcolston
replies.text: I personally think Biden is structurally a stronger opponent because he has institutional buy in that Trump never really had. But I understand the argument and agree that on a harm side.

replies.author: @jayware4219
replies.text: @Juniversal I won‚Äôt be withholding my vote. I‚Äôll be voting dem for local elections since I‚Äôm in a red state. National elections I think we need to be more strategic. You see every other group of people voting for their interests and if the candidates don‚Äôt give them what they want then their infrastructure will get everyone in line to vote for the officials that will give them what they want. We need to take note of how to actually wield our votes to get what we want and not just give our votes to people that have no intention to give us what we are demanding

author: @thr3385
text:
I lived in a red county in California often times no one would challenge the Republican candidate.

 Which is ridiculous.  You miss 100% of the shots that you never take. 

If you want progressive policies you have to vote for a progressive candidate and it's important for progressive candidates to run.

This is why we can't give up.

replies.text: @HeyLetsDoAThing not when your own condition is terrible. Self preservation is the first law. Black Americans have been bombed, burned and murdered for 200 years and the world didn't say a peep. Sending a few people out to white manufactured Black lives matter march doesn't mean squat

replies.author: @robwilkerson8139
replies.text:
Many support Trump because of his America First presidential record.  He had the best administration in decades!!  We had a 60-year record (or near record) of low unemployment and job growth for EVERY US demographic during 45's presidency!

Using existing legislation, Trump closed the border, and forced Mexico to pay for it by having them use thousands of their armed forces to keep people who cross the border illegally in Mexico, at Mexico's expense.   He cut taxes and cut regulations, which improved the economy for ALL Americans.  Unlike presidents before him, Trump demanded that our so-called allies start to pay their fair share of NATO defense spending.

Trump got rid of NAFTA and replaced it with a pro-American policy which is much better for US workers and  US businesses.  Unlike the unfulfilled promises of past presidents, Trump actually moved the American embassy in Israel to Jerusalem.  There were three mid-East peace treaties, at least two major terrorists bombed, NO NEW WARs and gas under $2.

These are just SOME of Trump's accomplishments as president and they illustrate the sound reasons that people support Trump.  Sadly, it seems the people who complain the most about Trump aways focus on his style and their own personal feelings rather than his actual populist successes. "But his Tweets were mean .... "     WAAAGH!!

replies.author: @robwilkerson8139
replies.text: America First!!  Trump 2024!!

replies.author: @MarkScott-
replies.text: @HeyLetsDoAThinghow does caring about the rest of the world advance black Americans to the next level

replies.author: @MarkScott-
replies.text: @robwilkerson8139America first but not tht trump ish.

replies.author: @robwilkerson8139
@HeyLetsDoAThing
replies.text: @MarkScott-A rising tide lifts all boats. You can‚Äôt just uplift black Americans and forget about the global plight of marginalized people. It just leads to black Americans joining the oppressor class without any fundamental change

text: A big thing people struggle with is admitting they were wrong.  It's why many conservatives would rather keep doubling down instead of accept any true argument from leftists. Ex. pointing out that Biden continued the child tax credit, it's not a Trump victory alone.

author: @jamesmcmillan2656
text: I‚Äôm an Australian progressive but follow world politics very closely. The right wing definitely controls the narrative through algorithms and the msm but the most powerful tool belongs to us. The truth. What Olay did to the mayor of new York would not have been possible if she was not armed with the truth. You guys and many others are imo the modern day equivalent to protest music in the 60s and seventies ( yes I‚Äôm that old lol ) before corporate America shut it down. Never stop doing what you are doing, much love.

author: @thr3385

replies.author: @OKANjarrod
replies.text:
How is it the "people" who need to be moved "Left" when, for example, even the majority of GOP voters support Universal Healthcare but Biden said he still would veto it after a global pandemic??

Like the one panelist said: "Stop talking to ni@@as like they stupid." The disconnect and disaffectedness doesn't come from "bad messaging". It comes from very intentional messaging that wants us to ignore our eyes and ears to play along rather than galvanizing support for a healthy multiparty system that would be forced to work for the people or get voted out, like it is in most of the Industrialized world. 

Identifying as an "abolitionist" while upholding the duopoly is a new one for me! There are multiple candidates that have actual abolitionist policies this time around. 

There is only a limited time before Ai machine learning usurps any chance for people power to have  lasting impact. How you use that time & your platform during that time will demonstrate what you're really about.

author: @thr3385
text:
The thing I take away from this most important is even when you're upset at the system you still should vote.

The uncommitted vote in Michigan is why we see the White House  changing their language when it comes to Israel. 

Sitting at home does nothing especially when we live in a country where millions of people do not vote.

replies.text: So proud of my fellow michiganders showing up for the uncommitted vote to send our message.

author: @Hawkaflocka91

author: @choicesii1
text:
That was a very refreshing discussion. I've noticed in about the last 5 years or so, there are many black and Latinos who have adopted a centrist point of view. It is generally along the lines of people are responsible for their own problems, and there is more opportunity now then ever and they can do more, but choose not to. Like anyone would ever choose to not have access to a good job, grow up impoverished, or somehow they were supposed to pull themselves from a mentality that they were supposed to develop where exactly? It's always along the lines of if I can change everyone else who is not me can also do it too, which is how no effective government anywhere in the world succeeds. 

It's clear these people dont understand basic civics, nor do they know anything about governments in other countries who operate effectively, or how elements within the government through compromise or directed bills tried to ensure that black people did not partake in what once was a progressive government. Much of the infrastructure in the US today was built mostly within a small timeframe that was then hindered by conservatives. Conservatives exist at this point to water down legislation, or stop it completely. I don't think Democrats are really that aware at how saboteur conservatives are. They think compromise is a good thing, and dont understand historically how it has hindered America from the start. The 3/5 human clause was a compromise. There has never been a good compromise. The real issue is you keep seeing legislation pass from a comprise that does not live up to what was promised, but you constantly see Democrats pat themselves on the back, and people become demoralized because it was watered down. 

You want to start reaching people then you have to start digging into the past and showing instances of what has been done. America has had a lot of great legislation that has been undone, and specifically made inaccessible to black people, Mexicans, and Native Americans. There's a reason you go to many major cities and there see empty factories. There's a reason where there once was major industrial cities that you see a lot of black people.

Yesss OLAY, change perspective

author: @SavageEntertainmentYEAH
text: I am so thankful to see strong black role models that are actively trying to educate the black community. We need to pay attention more to politics and stop turning an eye to this crap

author: @brownenerdygurl
text: This is leftist vs liberals conversation. Every presidential election year, it's easy to tell the difference. I think that we have to stop preaching "vote, vote, vote" and draw people in to organizing. Historically, legislation that benefitted us came as a result of protest and local grassroots upheavals. After these actions, THEN, the government moved the needle. The Michigan vote is a reflection of that. Rebellion by the people brings about change not conversations with legislators. America is an imperialist "nation"...they understand force and profit. Liberals always intellectualize conflict. They want to converse with politicians and have disdain for ignorance that busy, poor people may have  They believe in incrementalism instead of looking at radical action as an option (as true leftists historically have done). Incrementalism won't free Black people. It only makes us more comfortable within the capitalist system. Capitalism requires that poor people exist. So while some with be more comfortable, more will continue to suffer. Liberals are unwilling to take any risks.  That's a problem because poor people are becoming desperate, young people have lost hope and we're dealing with irrational people on the other side.

replies.author: @amoss9737
replies.text: This is so true. People want radical movement or at least an actual fight, some passion. There‚Äôs a reason people like Jasmine Crockett and Bernie Sanders are popular. They represent a fight and movement. Too many democrats represent a standstill. Nothing about that feels good.

author: @JenniferEllissolopreneur
text: So honored to hear from your amazing panel!

author: @GreenNectarines
text:
I appreciated a lot of this discussion. I just wish we had more discussions behind how we get out of this ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt have the big changes you need, now vote blue no matter who‚Äù situation. We do this every time and there‚Äôs no end in sight‚Ä¶ when are we tired? 

Also, how can we package the step by step voting strategy where the expectation is to vote for better policies little by little and eventually skewing left in a way that centers the Black lived experience? I hear the need to educate here but that is a double edged sword because many people don‚Äôt like being explained to‚Ä¶ but how do we make it abundantly clear via our actions and the situations faced by our people? On top of this‚Ä¶ idk how far left you will be able to skew. Any attempt at bringing the changes we need gets the McCarthyism treatment and I can‚Äôt speak for everyone but if you ask me? You skew left enough and that means a rejection of this entire system which defeats the purpose of hoping for a ‚Äúleft leaning bureaucratic system‚Äù‚Ä¶ I fear that if we can acknowledge that that imperialist component is part of the fabric of this country, we must also acknowledge that it is intentional and you‚Äôll see blood shed before you see it relinquish the reigns that keep the status quo going.

author: @clowny666

author: @laserspaceninja
text:
Gotta hand it to Reecie: that stat about 96% of the elected officials being local hit me hard. Go listen to that again then start looking into the people that affect your lives the most then vote and support good candidates: 1:02:02 

I'm not saying doing this will solve all of the problems but it is a good place to start as it is the way to be most affective for change. Plus isn't that where most people start political careers? Start there and play the long game then get the bigger changes later. Conservatives are---and have been---doing this since before Regan was elected.

author: @Zero_PE
text:
26:06 Fredrick said ‚Äúwe actually do really need more‚Äù and from what I‚Äôve been learning over the past few months from being in black radical spaces is that black people need to get involved in political organizations and develop media literacy, if they‚Äôre truly serious about wanting more than just the same BS around electoral politics every 4 years. 

We definitely need more black people to understand this so that we can develop an inside/outside game, elect politicians that support our interests and then hold them accountable when they don‚Äôt follow through with structural political organizations that focus on organizing around our issues. 

I get that that may be asking a lot because that requires a lot of people to become a lot more politically educated than they currently are, luckily that‚Äôs also the other thing that political organizations are good for.

I appreciate this conversation Olay! ‚úäüèæ

author: @nosedive1st
text:
Love these forums. So thank you and your contributors. 
I just wanted to state that when you don‚Äôt govern; meaning that when Republicans control one part of Congress or the other, and or even the White House, they don‚Äôt really govern beyond their tenets of giving money to the rich and monetizing quality of life every which way possible. When you don‚Äôt have a record on ANYTHING else, you have the advantage of not having to defend laws and programs that don‚Äôt get results right away. With that in mind, it‚Äôs easier to use hate and fear to create soundbites and empty stories that spread due to the lack of true journalism in this country. They tap into the systems they‚Äôve created while progressives try to educate and pass legislation that benefits everyone. Therein lies the disadvantage that‚Äôs always being faced, and not just every election cycle.

author: @shawnkelley1227
text: From a 70 year old progressive baby boomer, thank you all for this video. I first voted because as a teenager in the 60‚Äôs I saw it as my civic duty. As I voted year after year, I started to become more aware of issues and policy. I‚Äôm now totally aware that as a black man, the Democratic Party is my home. Call it a plantation, what ever, this is my family, my home, the people I trust to look out for my interest. I‚Äôm not a white supremacist or religious nationalist so no I can‚Äôt relate to the Republican Party in no way shape form or fashion. We have a 2 party system and it‚Äôs not gonna change anytime soon, so get in where you fit in and vote; it‚Äôs a right and your civic duty.

author: @masteroctagon6888
text: I think Olay you hit a good point around 48:18 about people viewing it as the politicians getting nothing done. I think a big root of this is how misinformed people are about US civics and voting process, which seems by design I think just look at our education system & average American‚Äôs literacy currently. I try to work on this locally & with family & friends - I always remind them if voting didnt matter, they wouldnt try disenfranchise so many or undermine the ways we can get involved.

author: @Dyvon.dynamo
text: 13:27 hit what I feel is missed in some of these panels: at times it feels like there is a lack of acknowledgement of the privilege of being a platform and place like this large enough to also be a counter narrative, and that lack of acknowledgement comes off as a intellectualist barrier. There are some points I've seen in a few of these panels that estrange folk who aren't as formally educated. Dude was on bars saying this acknowledgement because this whole panel tried to touch on how the lack of that privilege can also come off as lambasting them for their outlets, their mechanisms of news and their norms. This empathy is crucial if we all as black people being as myriad as we are to unify. üñ§üëäüèø

author: @lindagibbs428
text: Not voting at all is not the answer to me

author: @23phoenixash
text: 41:00 I can relate to what Olay is saying here because, even though I'm not an immigrant, I am a trans person and I've never felt the fear of my own community until Trump. A popular Youtuber recently attacked me because I challenged his "genocide Joe" rhetoric by simply stating that Trump would be even worse for Gaza. This Youtuber was very uncharitable and suggested that I didn't care about the Palestinian people, when the reality is I do, I'm just recognizing the broader reality that the winner of this election is going to be Trump or Biden and that there are other issues at stake than just the people of Gaza. I mean, if one believes Trump would do anything to help the Palestinian people, maybe they could try to put together some kind of argument that it's "worth it" to sacrifice women's reproductive health, trans people's freedom of expression, and/or the rights of people of color for the Palestinians. However, in this case, we already know Trump would be worse for the Palestinians because he has SAID he would be worse. So, I just don't understand the calculations people are making to help a person become president who has no upside whatsoever. I just picture profoundly privileged people, who won't be affected much regardless of who becomes president, snubbing their noses at shitty presidential options (as though we've ever NOT had shitty presidential options) rather than voting strategically and weighing the real costs to human lives. If you don't think it's worth it to vote for a president who is 1% better than the alternative, consider how many people would still be alive today if we had a president who had handled Covid 1% better (11,000 lives saved) or who might handle Israel/Gaza better (350 lives saved). The thing to remember is that every policy failure leads to tens of thousands of lives immiserated. The lesser of 2 evils is LESS evil. And even 1% less evil MATTERS.

author: @lloroshastar6347
text: The Labour Party in the UK has similar issues to the Democrats, not listening to minority voters, punishing anyone that speaks out against Israel (including many members of their own party), talking about Capitalist solutions to problems instead of talking about investing in our public services. But we do have an advantage in that the Labour party is currently 20 points ahead in the polls, and the Conservative government can try to gerrymander and use voter suppression, but one thing that isn't happening for them is the polls aren't closing, even with an election coming this year (likely before the US election), so there is now a movement over here to push tactical voting and trying to get more representation from smaller parties who do serve the people more. We can afford to do that without risking the Conservatives regaining power. Its a real shame that in the US if the vote is split it's a huge risk to hand the Republican's the election, but the US really does need more left-wing representation and the Democrats ain't it.

author: @samhill618
text: Rich people, or the affluent, especially when (we) get older tend to become more sadly conservative and more selfish. Add to that is the constant narrative in American capitalism of greed is good and ‚Äúeveryone can succeed by your bootstraps bullshit‚Äú, it‚Äôs not surprising some black people find it as appealing as white people (and poor white men listen to a narrative that treats them as the enemy still vote for active perpetrators, but often the Dems are just slightly less active in their damage).  As a white person, I try to tell other white people we would all work as one in the working class instead of fighting black and brown people or those in marginalised communities , then and only then will we get any progressive change and even then we have to fight the establishment constantly.  I‚Äôm also relatively well off but had to leave the states to make that happen, so unfortunately I have little influence.

author: @tommytommy1002
text: Someone tell me if I am looking at the solution to/for politicians addressing ours issues (black people) incorrectly / in the wrong way. We have never tried to consolidate the black vote, which would give us the power (politically) that other minority groups have. And in consolidating the black vote, we should demand that milestones are met and require explanation for not reaching those milestones. At this point, we decided if we move forward with this politician or look to someone else to meet our goals. What we do now is give out our vote , stand back and do nothing and then we are perplexed when those campaign promises are broken. (SURPRISE MF!) This is a nasty name to bring up, but the only person I can think of that tried to hold the black vote hostage is Diddy.

author: @Dominique129
text: I can't remember where she was speaking, but Hilary Clinton basically told voters who were on the fence or had issues with Biden to "get over themselves", and I just can't support that approach either. I think it can be pretty privileged to speak like that. In Michigan alone there was a notable uncommitted vote in the primaries due to the US continued support of Israel's government. I don't think that can be overlooked or ignored, not just politically, but more importantly for humanity. Yes I think we should save democracy, protect reproductive rights, and more. But, as a voter, I am tired of two-party political system and when a presidential election rolls around I need to just pick the candidate who is just palatable & then told now is still not the time to have more options politically. Love your videos, Olay!

replies.author: @shawnkelley1227
replies.text: It‚Äôs a 2 party system we have. Been that way for a long time. This election is not the one to complain against a 2 party system. This is not a change election, it‚Äôs a choice election. Vote and make a choice. 2028 will be a change election; believe me you will have plenty choices then; it still will be among the 2 parties. Vote for whoever you think is the best choice, do vote though; it‚Äôs a right that many died for, not a privilege. Get over it!

author: @cfsk6h34
text:
One problem I didnt hear addressed is why the conservatives "outnumber" liberal let alonr leftist voices. Neoliberalism is one thing, but to become a social minded leftist you have to have some sort of experience of inequality.

No experience of said discrepancy in experience means no trust in the ideology that leftists want:  affordable housing, education, healthcare etc not at tge individual but rather the national expense.

Yes christians believe in "good samaritans" but only if they recognize you as a neighbor and not a threat to their comfort. This is important because it determines what minority the neolibs are willing to dump in order to appease the conservative centrists (atm muslims, transgender peoples, chinese and mexicans)

The majority report just released a great interview reaction of by Mehdi Hassan, who got a democratic senator and wanna be future president to admit that saving 6 american lives would be worth 200+ dead palestinians.

Getting the big bucks on your side is not the solution, that money will never rival the military indistrial complex and petro lobbyists. The goal first and foremost should be messaging, people feel the systemic problems of late stage capitalism but have no words to describe it.

Meanwhile Republicans like Trump‚Äôs former NSA advisor John Bolton on TV saying we should be bombing Iran.  As I said, the handling of Gaza is indefensible and I dont begrudge that being a deal-breaker for anyone. However, how much it escalates beyond that and under what circumstances definitely will be impacted by who wins in November.

great vid...fan of everyone in the pannel but my one critique is
this convo kinda went in circles especially when it comes to the democrats(on the national level)..and seems kinda dependant on them (slightly, i know u all critique the party)
 when the democrats have ZERO interest in black causes...progressive or leftist things..and matter of ACTIVLEY combat those things harder then they do republican policies .and we cant call them a weaker enemy if that weaker enemy actively combats against u and dose not concede to you genuinely because then at that point  we a are talking about their aesthetics and not their function..so the real question is how do you work within a system and party that is actively against you?

(that being said focus on local elections is valid)

text: My vote for Biden is not for him, but for the people in his administration who are actually making a positive difference, like Lina Khan with the FTC and the NLRB.

author: @mfcolston
text: This is Gaza stuff is exactly why the Democrats lost back in 1968. You can have great and effective social policies, but if your foreign policy is liquidating whole populations, all those benefits are just bloody hush money. Also I agree, we should focus around community left issues rather than national politics. National politics can be so disempowering to the average person. Also  more feed back to be a non-partisan rather than a party operative.

author: @Social_Pugatory
text: 26:08 Is this Olay's show or is it Ben's?!  That was so rude. That man had a contribution to the conversation especially representing the black folks who are saying what he's saying. He may sounds ridiculous to us who engage with this conversation daily but he needs to be heard so that people who think the way he does can be challenged in realtime in a conversation like this. Ben should manage his emotions when on other folks platforms.

author: @AggrevatedDamage
text: My go to when it comes to the DNC is, they said that voting rights (John Lewis Voting Rights Act), was a priortity, they just needed our votes to get them in office first. We did that snd they promptly said it wasn't a priority and haven't spoken much about it since. But go back and look how quickly the Hate Against Asians Act passed (with some bi-partisan support) during Covid. And they think we forgot about that?!?!?!

author: @choicesii1
text: All votes are not equal, so the fact that 80 million people dont vote does not matter. We dont live in a democracy. It's more important to note who didn't vote in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Florida, Georgia, Wisconsin, North Carolina, Virginia, or any state where you have a margin that can make a difference in shifting the balance of power.
